/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: Thanks for the review, Charles! A clear sign that I should write some tests 😄

Switched to batches-per-revert for the config option instead of suffixes-per-batch -- this way, ops shouldn't need to touch the config as much. For example, suppose you've got a handful of suffix dirs that raise ENODATA when you try to stat or list them, in a partition that's got a few thousand suffixes. You take it as a sign that the disk is failing, and try to drain the disk before removal to save some effort.

On master, we'd hand all the suffixes over to rsync, which would eventually fail. Some data may have moved, but the failure meant that we wouldn't delete any of it, so the disk would never fully drain.

With the original config option, you could set rsync_max_suffixes_per_revert to something like 60 and expect to need 30-50 batches to move everything. If you hit an ENODATA, say, 10 batches in, the next cycle again tries to move 60 suffixes per batch, but now only needs to move 20-40 batches' worth since we delete what we can after each batch. Replication will continue to choke on that ENODATA, but the suffix shuffling should mean you'll continue to make progress -- up to a point. Once all remaining suffixes fit in a single batch, you never get a clean rsync. You have to adjust the suffixes-per-revert down if you want to continue deleting the remaining good data.

Now, you could set rsync_batches_per_revert to something like 50, so on the first pass batches are around 40-60 suffixes each. Let's say you hit that ENODATA around halfway through -- the next pass, you're down to 20-30 suffixes per batch since we don't have as many total suffixes. Replication will continue failing, but the batch size will keep decreasing as long as we're deleting some data. As long as you've got less than 50 bad suffixes, all the good data should get replicated off eventually.

This seems like a reaonably well justified idea - i can imagine it helping.

I'll have to try to get probetests passing with a non-default value!

Is this defaults/main.yml, tasks/main.yml or vars/main.yml (or some other location in the role)?

Setting facts is expensive - it requires running a task. Every task run costs more time.

https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/user_guide/playbooks_variables.html#tips-on-where-to-set-variables indicates that variables are inherited from one role to another. Why not use defaults/main.yml or vars/main.yml instead?

The load of defaults/vars from a role is done automatically when the role is included/imported without the need for an additional task.

Also consider the fact that ansible variables are evaluated lazily. It only needs the variable when it is accessed via a task or template. This means that we can set variables in vars/defaults which reference things like facts or other set facts.

that would be a question for Bogdan. I'm not sure what he had in mind here.

However he doesn't explicitly say the plan is to set facts. If you look at the vars file that already exists in some of the proposed standalone roles, there are several instances of variable composition and references to reduce re-use. I think that would be preferred approach instead of set_fact tasks.

Jesse, I agree that facts are expensive but I don't think we should forbid them. We should warn about them and encourage their minimization. At the same time, there are a lot of complicated expressions to translate from the old language to the new and fact setting can help with that [0].

Thus, I've added new copy to the proposed text which warns against fact setting but allows it to be used in certain cases. I hope this addresses your concern. I think at this stage of the project it's better to use the facts in some cases and get working code sooner. Forbidding completely them seems like premature optimization [1]. Instead use them sparingly.

[0] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-ansible/+/842152/32/tripleo_ansible/roles/tripleo_nova_libvirt/tasks/main.yml#75
[1] https://stackify.com/premature-optimization-evil/

IMHO, mapping and transforming to THT parameters to ansible vars/puppet hiera (with all kinds of available heat intrinsic functions) is one of the key features of the THT atm. We probably would need a official tool to do that without THT. Expecting users to understand these transformations and provide appropriate variables would probably be too much to ask(?).

Also, we would possibly end up with 'n' times ansible variables as compared to THT parameters with all the proposed dedicated role and service vars. Heat parameters have descriptions which helps in understanding their usage, which we've to provide for all ansible vars and possibly ensure that with linting checks.

I probably have explained this poorly. The intent is to not request knowing ansible variables mappings to t-h-t/puppet from users, but from roles developers and tripleo maintainers, to keep them synced, especially when backporting changes around. And the helper script, like that example that I linked, is intended to help developers with that task. While for the end users, indeed, official tooling would be very nice to have, to help them to convert their deployment data into new format consumed for ansible. Or maybe have them keep using heat when converting it via tripleo DF, and passing as group vars. That just a detail of how tripleo would support user inputs further, after the standalone roles come into reality.

Are we expecting users to create/update the inventory manually vs. auto generated atm? How would it work with baremetal provisioning which generates bits of the inventory from neutron data? Are we going to change that to also generate in these formats and structure(?).

playbooks/setup-infrastructure.yml.message:
didn't we agree yesterday that it's not necessary?

our reason behind that was to avoid unexpected ceph upgrade but as it turns out it won't happen if upgrade_ceph_packages=False(default value).

In that case, I'll personally prefer to leave it as it is.
Especially when we explicitly say in our docs that integrated ceph is not recommended scenario, we shouldn't care much about these things in my opinion.

Ceph is a storage layer. So it can be compared with networking setup but not with galera/rabbitmq/memcached. And we do not provide any default way for networking configuration. So Ceph is not infrastructure from my understanding and has nothing to do with it.

For me ceph still has nothing to do with infrastructure - there's no logic in that. It's quite independent thing, but fully eligible for setup-everything.

Also for usecase that was mentioned yesterday - folk is running setup-infrastructure periodically to ensure config state. While it make sense to run same for ceph, but I'm not sure about including ceph into same periodic run (as example).

But ok, I will propose alternative patch with documentation changes only so we can select.

thanks Dmitriy

one small note according to: "For me ceph still has nothing to do with infrastructure".
I think it depends on a perspective.
I have ceph integrated with OSA, so for me ceph is definitely a part of my infrastructure, the same as rabbitmq, memcached etc.
I do agree with Damian here: Ceph cluster's control plane is part of the infrastructure _for_ OpenStack and it should be deployed prior to Glance/Cinder/<other _OpenStack_ services>.

src/config.yaml.message: I know it may seem odd, but all variables in a config.yaml have a tradition of being '-' (dash) separated, not '_' (underscore) separated.

I'd prefer to keep these options removed from the charm for the time being and not exposed until we determine it is strictly necessary. Enabling these options also requires that the userstat is set to 1 within the mysql database. As such, enabling these options will require that the user do more than just toggle the option - which will be confusing when they don't show up while enabled.

I am aware that the snap has these options as something that can be enabled, but that is because the snap *may* be installed by more users than just the charm (since it lives in a generally consumable space). The charm can be more opinionated about which settings it exposes. Also, I will note that there are a number of other options that the prometheus exporter provides (and the snap supports) that are not reflected in the configuration here. After discussion with database expertise, its recommended to just keep the default options for the exporter in most cases so let's run with that for the time being.
Where is the 'install_method' option exposed ? It doesn't seem to be a charm config option

I am agree with you that prom prefix is not readability here. But I am not sure about the `get_` prefix for the property function. Usually @property + noun means getter function in python. I would like to change to `prometheus_exporter_username` instead of `get_exporter_name` here.
Could you add a doc string to explain this? I don't follow why localhost is being added if the requested cluster address is in self.cluster_address
I have no problem with the conditional block, I just don't think it's intuitive. But I won't block on that comment.

The code is same here https://git.launchpad.net/charm-mysql-innodb-cluster/tree/src/lib/charm/openstack/mysql_innodb_cluster.py#n546

The "localhost" is added here for the mysql permission. If there are three instances A, B, and C. The permissions will be 'user'@'A', 'user'@'B', 'user'@'C', and 'user'@'localhost'. And the 'localhost' permission will be created by when local hook fire.

We can remove the if check, but the behavior will be the same. Because permission will be added only in write-allow node. And skip if write-only or permission exists.
(fix)Skip if read-only or permission already exists.
This method seems to be almost identical to create_cluster_user, I think it would be good to see if it's possible to refactor this pr to have a common create_user method
Update: I refactored create_cluster_user and create_prometheus_user function.

The permission we need is almost the same as create_cluster_user, the only different are grant permission function and read_only parameter.

I would like to keep both permission functions is because there are only two permission functions now, and I use Mixin to separate them. And it would also be more flexible if there are some change on one of the permission, it would not affect another one.

There's no error handling/logging if this goes wrong.  If, for example, the snap store is unavailable, then this will just go bang, and produce a stacktrace.  It would be a much nicer user experience if the error was trapped, and error message logged, and the status updated and then the hook fails.

Alex's point here is very valid; layer-snap will just bubble up the exceptions which will end up causing this hook to simply error out. While the hook will error out, users will need to go to the logs to make sense of a stack trace to figure out what to do. It's possible that may be the case in the long run, but it is better to help the user understand if there is something they need to pay attention to. For example, the status of the unit could report that the snap installation failed or something to that extent which at least gives the user an idea of *why* it went into error.

releasenotes/notes/authz-rule-55a6db5434.message:
Just for my understanding on the difference between admin-rule and authorization-rule:
The admin-rule in the tenant configuration was renamed to authorization-rule because it is used to validate that a user is authorized depending on whatever criteria are specified by this rule. The tenant attribute on the other hand is still called admin-rule because it really tells that the linked authorization-rule will enable admin access to the tenant. We did that split to allow further levels of authorization on for a tenant (let's call it something like a "moderator" or some kind of "privileged user" for a tenant). Did I understand that correctly?
Exactly (though in this case, the next level is going to be "read access" instead of "moderator", but this would support that case as well).

zuul/model.py.message: In the Python code it looks like admin_rules and authorization_rules are just exchanged (so one becomes the other), but I assume this is more like a cleanup step to align on the new values.

Yes -- an authz rule is generic (it doesn't say what it authorizes, it's just the set of criteria).  But when it's applied to restrict access to administrative functions, it's an admin rule.

That distinction is now important since we will authorize to multiple things, and this change aligns them.

zuul/model.py.message: Was this change to info intentional? Using self.log makes sense but not sure if you wanted to keep the same level or not.

It's intentional, but it's not a change -- self.warning is the helper method which appends the message to the "Warnings" section of the code-review report and also logs it at info level in the Zuul log.  So here we're just dropping it from the warning section (since it now shows up in the error_detail of the specific job) but continuing to send it to the Zuul log as info.

> Patch Set 1: Code-Review-2
> 
> This needs to be seriously discussed, because we have to take into consideration many things.
> Currently we can do multiple parallel backups, and we can have multiple processes in a single Backup service, and we have the "backup_max_operations" configuration option to limit the concurrency so we don't run out of memory or go overboard with the CPU.
> 
> Adding this without careful consideration would be a regression for many people, as their backup services may blow up.

While I agree that all cinder services must not choke the machine to death even with a full queue of stuff to do (as in: many backups being requested) and do so over a longer period of time munching away on the queue.

But having more parallelism / threads working on the chunks of a single backup is "just" another factor for the potentially total threads running.
And it's less about having all those threads consume CPU cycles but to fight the latency of talking to (remote) (object) storage as well, right?

In short: I'd rather have that single backup be done quicker (using more cores and parallelism) and do less concurrent backups and the performance numbers with a single thread are just unbearable.
Thanks for review. With default value of 1, we are not change current behaviour. Consider scenario where large volume needs to backup instead of multiple small volumes.

Sorry, but I believe the threading you are using in the patch would give you greenthreads, not native threads, and in any case we already have support for what this patch is trying to do.

Please look at the "backup_native_threads_pool_size" and "backup_max_operations" configuration options.

The --cni-bin-dir argument is only applicable to dockershim, which we don't use, so we should be able to remove it unconditionally. TTLAfterFinished has defaulted to "true" since K8s 1.21, so again we should be able to remove it unconditionally.

RemoveSelfLink could be a problem, we first set it to false in 1.21, and there are comments in https://review.opendev.org/c/starlingx/config/+/817283 about how it's a problem:

 "Also, k8s deprecated/removed RemoveSelfLink config in feature-gates in k8s 1.21. This causes PVCs to not bound PVs automatically, which eventually causes failure of installation of apps like WRA, auditd and vault. The script modifies this config to RemoveSelfLink=false to mitigate these failures"

When it comes to cleaning up keys that need to be removed, for example if a user enables hw-offload and then wants to remove it. There are two ways I can picture we handle this, we can add an if statement in here. 
```
- name: Configure OVS other_config
  ansible.builtin.shell: >
    ovs-vsctl set open . {% for key, value in other_config.items() %} other_config:{{ key }}={{ value }} {% endfor %}
    {%- if not tripleo_enable_hw_offload %}
     && ovs-vsctl remove open . other_config hw-offload
    {% endif -%}
```

Doesn't look nice, but it will be quick.

Or, we can create a cleanup playbook, which is obviously a cleaner and more elegant way of handling it. The cleanup playbook could work out the logic of what needs to be removed and remove it in separate tasks, or maybe we just have one shell task that runs through a bunch of if statements and removes things as required in a single task.

The situation I'm thinking about is that we may have operators do all the 'configure' tasks, perhaps even pre-maintenance... because it doesn't change anything that's running. Then in a maintenance slot they do the 'run' tasks to activate the changes.

I wonder if it would make sense to have the 'configure' tasks here just put down a file or script or something that prepares the changes... then the 'run' tasks execute the script.

Think about it like putting down a dnf transaction file in 'configure', then executing the transaction file in 'run'. Does that make sense?

One reason for the intent with task separation between install/configure/run/etc is as Jesse describes:

"The situation I'm thinking about is that we may have operators do all the 'configure' tasks, perhaps even pre-maintenance... because it doesn't change anything that's running. Then in a maintenance slot they do the 'run' tasks to activate the changes."

It's been stated that we need to be able to stage all our configuration changes and then "flip a switch" so they take effect. Likewise, we should be designing things with similar support for rollback as well. I know we're not there yet, but that's the intent.

For this case, I'd tend towards finding a way to stage this config change (the bash script is one approach). Or, move it to run.yaml, or perhaps a bootstrap.yaml. Bootstrap tasks might cover "things we need to do to a running service to make it work the way we want".

I'm glad this has come up, b/c it helps us refine the spec and think about the right approach!

Na, OvS needs to be running to configure these settings unfortunately. I'm not too sure about dropping a bash script to do it. Seems like that would add complexity when it could be done with Ansible during this execution. But I'm happy to let the majority rule on this one. My opinion is that we make an exception for this given that we can't configure it like we can with other services that read from a .conf file. So I would be in favour of leaving this as the exception here.

But if the majority prefer a bash script dropped at this point and then executed during configure, I'm happy to oblige.

We could probably safely assume that OvS is installed and running before this role is executed. But I thought it best to not rely on that assumption and allow this role to function in a truely standalone manner.

Ok, I added a bootstrap.yml for this task. The reason I don't think run.yml is the right place for it is just because we're talking about running ovn-controller here. It just has a dependency on OvS to work. So to me, it makes more sense if we handle this separately in the suggested bootstrap.yml file.

We could probably safely assume that OvS would be running. But making that assumption would mean this is less standaloney. I think it's better that we ensure prereqs here somewhere and bootstrap.yml makes the most sense to me.

specs/xena/rDNS-nonoctet-boundary.rst.message:
This goes straight into the solution (RFC 2317), with little commentary on the problem that is being solved.
As neutron will create and manage reverse zones, it's not clear initially why this change is needed.
It would be helpful to have a problem description that describes the case where not all of a class "C" subnet is delegated to the OpenStack deployment, such that some of the reverse PTR records may live outside of the Designate controlled zones. I think you need a way to delegate portions of a reverse zone to neutron/designate from an existing or shared zone.

I would like to see a small example of the configuration required in the parent zone here. It helps to frame the manual work required that is not addressed by this specification.
From this spec, you cannot see end-to-end how this would work in practice.

Can we explicitly call out the proposed new settings in the neutron configuration file here?

Are you proposing a "ipv4_ptr_zone" configuration setting for every possible subnet created in neutron?

To me, it's not clear that either of these settings could be set globally in the neutron configuration file. The parent delegation size could vary subnet to subnet right?
You need a blank line here to have the bulleted list render correctly.
Do new global setting make sense here? Maybe all we need is settings on the subnet and/or IP allocation pool.

How is this exposed via the API to set?
Is this set a subnet creation time? SubnetPool creation?
Is this tied to a specific IPAM implementation?

It seems like the logical place to configure this would be at the subnet level, such that all of the addresses in the allocation pool would use the alternate ptr_zone.

If this is config option change only, I don't see any reason why we need to store it in the db.
If You want to do it "per subnetpool" maybe You should make it as API extension to allow setting that template for each subnetpool per API?
I agree, the option would need to be per subnet, since there may be different schemes in use in parallel, and then the most reasonable approach would be to have an API extension for it.

Can we see more of an end-user use case here?

Something like:

User requests a PTR zone delegation
User creates a subnet, specifying the ptr_zone that was delegated.
User sets "dns_publish_fixed_ip"
User creates a port on the network with a DNS name and IP
User can reverse look up the IP

I am wondering if this is going to add confusion/support issues. Currently, if the DNS integration with designate isn't configured or isn't working, the user gets back an "openstacklocal" domain, which clearly indicates it's using internal neutron DNS.
With this change, how will users know if they are using "private" neutron internal DNS, or if it's actually published in an external DNS service such as Designate?
I think the port view information will now be the same, but in the case of private neutron internal DNS, it won't be resolvable from outside neutron.

What needs to be clarified in this spec is that we are adding an extension, let's call it for now 'dns_domain_ovn'. This extension is a subclass of 'dns_domain_keywords', which inherits from all the other dns integratrion extensions: https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/6db61d070483df60ffbf992d57cef2c1903fe355/neutron/plugins/ml2/extensions/dns_domain_keywords.py#L25-L31

When this new extension is configured without specifying an external_dns_driver in the neutron config file (https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/6db61d070483df60ffbf992d57cef2c1903fe355/neutron/conf/common.py#L87-L88) we will get the same behavior as described in reference [0] below, but without sending the record any external DNS service like Designate. Of course the user might choose to configure the external_dns_service, in which case records would be created in the external dns service

Ok, so if I understand you correctly, if the dns_domain_ovn extension is enabled, no external DNS extension *can* be enabled, so that is the signal to a user that DNS records on the ports are only visible from inside the tenant networks. Is that correct?

We have been working on this spec under the explicit assumption (see lines highlighted) that it will be complemented on the Nova side by this spec: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova-specs/+/840974. However, recently the Nova team has decided to address the use case in a manner that doesn't require any cooperation from Neutron. They came up with a spec (https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova-specs/+/849765) that went from original submission to approval in matter of a five days and then they reverted it, due to opposition within their core team. Currently, they are planning to discuss again how to address the use case in the Antelope cycle with this spec: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova-specs/+/850352. Still, the proposed alternatives don't require cooperation from Neutron.

As a consequence, we should put this spec on hold. Let's watch the conversation on the Nova side during the Antelope cycle, in the unlikely case that something might be needed from Neutron.

I disagree. Exposing the network's dns_domain in DHCP is completely independent of Nova, and only relies on Nova's metadata to the extend that we'd like to give cloud-init the same information as DHCP to avoid cloud-init clobbering the DHCP-derives dns_domain. For guests without cloud-init, or guests where cloud-init's configuration disabled dns_domain management, this spec is still very useful, and can stand on its own.

In Octavia this mechanism is disabled by default, but in tempest this test was always enabled. I added a configuration setting for tempest.conf now so that this test will also be disabled by default. Thanks for your comment.

If you're using devstack for testing, you'll need to make sure failover_threshold and health_check_interval are configured in octavia.conf as in jobs.yaml. When I tested it a long time ago, it worked reliably in my devstack environment. However currently it seems to fail because of an unrelated bug (which remains to be investigated).

That said, that whole failover circuit breaker mechanism has a timing aspect to it, which makes it very difficult to make the scenario test 100% reliable. The implementation relies on the heartbeat information in the data base and the test has no direct control over it. It may happen that a failover gets triggered before the threshold limit gets reached and that would make the test fail. This won't be issue in a real world scenario, but here it is. That is also the main reason why I made the job non-voting.

What I tried now is to create the two load balancers in parallel instead of one after the other. That way I the heartbeat signals from the amps should be more aligned with each other. I also tweaked the health_check_interval a bit.

Thanks for all the information.
In octavia-tempest-plugin we only have tempest.conf afaik. Do we have a default value for the failover cb in octavia.conf? Is it enabled by default in octavia? 

Usually in octavia-tempest-plugin we enable features which are disabled by default with a flag in tempest.conf

Is that the same issue? It looks different... the context of this is that the MTU of the VIF follows the definition of the Neutron network, so it can change during live-migration (which libvirt cannot support).

nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py.message:
im not sure this is the correct placce to check.

we shoudl should proably be using the destination vifs form the migrate data object

since we need to check if the destination vifs will hae a differnt mtu form the source vifs.


the network info cache will still have the source vif info so that not corect to check at this point

Hmm, why would this not be the right place? This is the live migration checks at source/dest that the conductor does before committing any changes for the live-migration. We need the domain XML at the source to compare to the Neutron network.

---

From what I can gather, the VIFMigrateData/destination VIFs are just deep-copied source VIFs i.e., they are hydrated with instance.get_network_info() and only other fields like binding profile are replaced for the destination. I can drag the migrate_data over from check_can_live_migrate_destination() though as it's still a bit clearer.

Though, more importantly, your mention of this makes me realize we probably need to use network_api.get_instance_nw_info() to hydrate the VIFMigrateData, not the instance info cache. Fresh network info is what pre_live_migration() uses and that's not called until *AFTER* conductor calls the check code (here).

Right now we use cached instance info which could be stale if a user changes a Neutron network and then immediately fires off a live-migration. In which case we might let a live-migration through the pre-checks here that still fails later.

What do you think?

When we talked about "should we infer dev_id_bytes from the array" there was a question about seemingly conflicting values of "prefer explicit to implicit" vs "prefer single-source-of-truth in data as opposed to writing the same data twice"

I think we should go with explicit-single-source-of-truth

during deserialization we have to read dev_id_bytes to build the arrays, afterwards we don't need it as an attribute

during serialization we must calculate our dev_id_bytes to fit the array, and write it down so we can read the array later

so there's really ONLY the value in serialized data structure and we can't not write it, do we really need/want to expose it as a property at all?

deliverables/yoga/ironic.yaml.message: The same comments would also valid for ironic yoga as for xena and wallaby versions, but unfortunately the 20.2.0 version is already taken on stable/zed...

I can accept if the team wants to release all with only PATCH version bumps.
(The question is, what would a consumer prefer: to have a better matching semantic version OR to have a matching bump for all the stable branches)

So:
- just a new added requirement, not a changed one
and
- we cannot consistently bump as a minor version across all branches


I think my preference would be to just release as a patch version. I'd certainly prefer that to doing a mix of minor and bugfix bumps for different branches.

What do you think?

This disables CFS CPU quota to avoid performance degradation due to

doc/source/release-notes/zed.rst.message: I found this confusing on first reading. Is this another way of saying that channel `latest/stable` on Focal for all OVN charms is now pointing at track 22.03 ?
No. More background can be found here: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1FBxtRHIYMuM7BXlsyzKp-9x-3Fsp2TzvYz_ymOFb7Pc/edit?usp=drivesdk

I first interpreted this as being related to the new default track. Let's refactor:

===
The OVN charms in track 22.03 and later now default to installing OVN 22.03 for fresh deployments on Focal. This has no effect when upgrading the OVN charms or when scaling an existing application (new units). However, a new configuration option `ovn-source`_ has been added that can override this behaviour (i.e. payload upgrades will be triggered by charm upgrades and scaling).

* Make sure to edit the link label at the bottom of the page.
===

How do other charms work in terms of charm upgrades and application scaling not affecting what latest/stable is pointing at? It looks like there is something particular going on here when maybe it shouldn't?

+++++++++++++++++++++

Off-topic,

I do find option `ovn-source` dubious in terms of its ability to influence what payload version gets installed. This seems to be in conflict with the central notion of channels.

There is also a lot of wording in this option's description (config.yaml) that needs improvement and clarification:

* terminology "overlay repository" is new (to me)
* we're hardcoding versions (not great)
* it's not clear what values can be used
This does not relate to the default track.

The first sentence is still awkward. Users will expect to have 22.03 installed if they choose track 22.03. I've done this on Focal and it worked fine (our documentation also states that track 22.03 can already be used with Focal). IIUC, due to the ovn-chassis subordinate charm, it is not possible to guarantee that 22.03 will be installed using current methods but it would be if a new UCA pocket was used. It is this change that the release note should be pointing out. 

Please validate this suggested text:

===
On Focal, deployments of the OVN charms when using track 22.03 (``--channel 22.03/stable``) will use a new PPA-backed UCA pocket. This is to ensure that a machine can simultaneously have OpenStack components from one source and OVN components from another.

This has no effect when upgrading the OVN charms or when scaling an existing application (new units). However, a new configuration option `ovn-source`_ has been added that can override this behaviour (i.e. payload upgrades will be triggered by charm upgrades and scaling).
===

* Make sure to edit the link label at the bottom of the page

Thank you for the suggested update to the text, it looks like a great improvement.

Both the existing cloud archive pockets and the new one are PPA-backed, so I'm not sure if it's useful to point that out in this context. What about "...will use a new OVN specific UCA pocket" instead?

I'll put up a patch set with that and we'll se how it looks. Thanks!

nodepool/tests/unit/test_driver_kubernet.message:
Typically, we would expect to use a facility like 'annotations' rather than 'labels' because we don't expect
to query or identify these namespaces, and this change does not do that.  However, by using labels instead of annotations, we retain the ability to potentially do that in the future.  Is that the reasoning for this choice?

(Incidentally, I do not think that we should add any features which rely on querying labels now; this driver needs to be converted to the statemachine interface, and the simpler we keep this, the easier that will be.)

The reasoning was rather that we need to identify nodepool-managed namespaces in the cleanup process. This is done via the namespaces metadata (analogous to openstack server metadata).
The way this metadata is set currently [1] does not work and is simply ignored by k8s. It must be stored either as metadata.labels or metadata.annotations. So we need to add either of those anyway. Thus, I decided to go with labels as I think the values we set there (node_id, provider_name, pool_name) match the semantics of identifying attributes of a k8s object.

[1] https://opendev.org/zuul/nodepool/src/commit/4dcbf41259/nodepool/driver/kubernetes/provider.py#L139
-1: Add watermark_sleep=1 to useNodepool, and then add pool.cleanup_interval = 1.  Those will make this run a lot faster (a few seconds instead of a few minutes).

nodepool/driver/kubernetes/provider.py.message:
I just left a comment on another change advocating keeping memory specified as MiB since memory is customarily measured in MiB, and by that logic, this should be MB since that's how storage is customarily measured.

In retrospect, perhaps neither of these should be integers and instead should be strings.  Maybe we should fix that when we move it to Zuul.
I think we should be consistent here and also use MiB as we do for the memory limits.

As an intermediate step, we could also try to cast it to int, treating it as MiB (memory) or MB (storage), and as a fallback just pass it as a string, allowing the user to specify the unit of its choice. So with a deprecation notice we can eventually get rid of the (somewhat inconsistent) int interpretation and only support explicit units.

cinder/api/v3/attachments.py.message: Full disclosure: I don't know what this setting of connection_info from volume admin metadata is for, so I tried to change it as minimally as possible.

This shouldn't be changed, if we're expecting a format change in volume then the admin metadata also needs to be updated. see my comments in remotefs.py file

Sofia: This is specific for file system type drivers so RBD won't be running this code path.

Right, on the nova side we store the connection_info which AFAICT is only available from the attachment info. We use the connection_info to generate the XML for the instance:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/1025c9879341d44db33c4cc501435364dd185a9e/nova/virt/libvirt/volume/nfs.py#L29

Currently, the connection_info for the attachment says format "raw" after the volume snapshot. Is that accurate?

Sorry, I don't know how the snapshots work and why the snapshot would be made the active file for the instance. And why the connection_info would not be updated at the same time the snapshot is made the active file.

In PS1, you are updating the format irrespective of the volume is attached or not. if you only update the format when volume is attached then it should not fail.
But i think the problem is bigger than this. Nova is using attachment information to track the snapshot format (which is the active file from nova side) but on cinder side, we have attachment records associated with the volume and not snapshot. I think this requires some discussion between both nova and cinder teams.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: Please describe *how* they fix the use-case.  I can see that you're adding a timeout in one case and checking the return code of systemctl in another case, but that doesn't tell me how this fixes the original problem.

It is necessary to restart kubelet because when an wrong configuration is set in any of the k8s control plane components, kubelet makes a maximum of 5 attempts to restart the erroneous component. If we reach the limit, no matter if we correct the configuration during the automatic recovery, the container does not starts again.

Will wait for your test results so we know if at least we have a solution for the cyclic deps with this approach. I understand that this will also bring the fluxcd app deployment "closer" to what was on Armada, prob making it quicker to apply.

I'm just unsure if disabling this wait is the correct approach here.
What you could also test is to resolve the cyclic deps by placing the same hooks/weights to those templates, ensuring the resources will try to come up at the same time.

I just finished the test results and the approach worked. I will now test the alternative approach that you suggested regarding placing correct weights in the pods/jobs.

For this alternative approach will be needed an patch for the openstack-helm. I tried to avoid this just to put the openstack-helm version that we use close to the upstream, but it is definitely something that needs to be discussed to check if it is a better approach for this issue.

I was not able to change the order just by using helm.hook and helm.weight. Looks like helmv3 has a installOrder that takes place before the resources be ordered by weight (https://github.com/helm/helm/blob/release-3.3/pkg/releaseutil/kind_sorter.go#L31).I don't know if it is possible to override this order so we can install the deployment after all jobs are executed. If anyone know if this is possible or if this is really the best approach in compare with the one purposed by this issue, please let us know so we can implement the solution.

tests/unit/test_scheduler.py.message:
I find this comment to be a bit confusing. It appears we're actually explicitly refreshing the pipelines below to refresh the JobData. Is this saying that the pause is necessary for the pipeline refresh to trigger a job refresh when we manually trigger pipeline refreshes?

Additionally, do we expect both pipeline refreshes to attempt to refresh job data or just the second one (which affects the paused job)?

There's a lot of "refreshing" going on, so let me explain... no let me summarize:

* Not only does JobData rarely change, but the objects that hold JobData (which are either FrozenJob or Build objects) also rarely change.
* The comment above is explaining why we are using a paused job: that is one of the times when a Build is refreshed, and that is a necessary pre-requisite to refreshing a Build's JobData.  In other words, to even have a chance of calling the code that decides whether or not to refresh a Build's JobData from ZK, we first have to call the code that refreshes Build.
* That means that "refreshPipelines" doesn't always refresh every object in all the pipelines.
* So if we want to verify that we are re-using JobData objects, we need to refresh a pipeline when it is in a condition where it will decide that it needs to refresh the Build so that we can test our JobData reuse code.

So to answer your question: refreshPipelines *does* cause us to execute the JobData hash matching code because the content of the pipeline is a paused build.  If it were any other build, we wouldn't even get that far so the test would not be useful.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: Not approving as there is a git thing affecting testing. Feel free to approve when that is resolved.

zuul/model.py.message: Do we need to load the data from zk if the hash is None as well? To avoid a None hashes allowing data to leak across?

I don't believe there is a code path that allows for the serialized JobData object to have a None value for its hash.  However, existing_job_data may itself be None, which is why we have the getattr (so that we don't raise an AttributeError).  I suppose it may be marginally more safe to add "and job_data['hash'] is not None" onto the end, but it should not be possible to hit, so I'm not sure it's worth it.
